data.name: Top Coins
data.description: Top cryptocurrencies by market cap. The S&P 500 of crypto.

data.name: Smart Contract Platform
data.description: Smart contract platforms are usually blockchains that host smart contracts or decentralized applications. Users can interact with different smart contracts on these platforms to perform various actions such as lending and borrowing funds, staking their assets or minting NFTs. Smart contracts are programs that are stored on the blockchain and are automatically executed when certain conditions are met.

data.name: Layer 1
data.description: Layer 1 serves as the primary and autonomous chain on which transactions are directly executed and confirmed, as well as providing the essential infrastructure for the blockchain network.

data.name: Proof of Work
data.description: Proof of Work (PoW) is a blockchain consensus mechanism to validate transactions and create new blocks through computational efforts by miners.

data.name: World Liberty Financial Portfolio
data.description: The World Liberty Financial portfolio includes purchases made by the World Liberty Financial project. World Liberty Financial is a DeFi project associated with U.S. presidential candidate Donald Trump and his family members.

data.name: Proof of Stake
data.description: Proof of Stake (PoS) is a blockchain consensus mechanism where validators are selected to create new blocks based on the amount of cryptocurrency they hold and are willing to stake as collateral.

data.name: Made in USA
data.description: Refers to cryptocurrencies that have significant connections to the United States, either through their founding team or company headquarters.

data.name: Alleged SEC Securities
data.description:
Tokens and cryptocurrencies alleged to be securities by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). 

Note: The labeling of these cryptocurrencies as securities by the SEC doesn't equate to the legal classification till proven in a court.

data.name: Exchange-based Tokens
data.description: These tokens are associated with both centralized and decentralized exchanges which share the same purposes such as enjoy discounted trading fees and gain access to exclusive token sales on the exchange. While decentralized exchanges tokens also function as governance as a governance tokens, centralized exchange token does not.

data.name: Made in China
data.description: Refers to cryptocurrencies that have significant connections to the China, either through their founding team or company headquarters.

data.name: Centralized Exchange Token
data.description: These utility tokens are issued by a centralized exchange and can be used for a variety of purposes. Although holders are not able to exercise governance, they still carry many other benefits such as enjoy discounted trading fees and gain access to exclusive token sales on the exchange.

data.name: Decentralized Finance
data.description: Decentralized Finance, is a financial system that operates without central authorities or intermediaries, using blockchain technology and smart contracts to provide a range of financial services such as lending, borrowing, and trading.

data.name: CoinList Launchpad
data.description: CoinList is a platform specializes in compliant token launches for new projects.

data.name: Liquid Staking Tokens
data.description: Liquid staking token is a tokenized representation of staked tokens that can be traded or used in various DeFi applications.

data.name: Liquid Staking
data.description: Liquid staking is a process in which users can stake their cryptocurrency tokens to earn rewards while maintaining the ability to use or trade those tokens in DeFi applications.

data.name: Real World Assets
data.description: Real World Assets (RWAs) refer to tangible or physical assets that have value in the real world. The tokenization of RWAs involves representing these assets digitally on a blockchain, allowing for fractional ownership, increased liquidity, and more efficient management and trading of these assets.

data.name: Meme
data.description: Meme coins derive their relevance from memes, thriving on hype and picking up momentum as the community grows.

data.name: Governance
data.description: A governance token grants its holders the right to influence, vote, or decide on changes to a blockchain protocol, dApp, or DAO.

data.name: Dog-Themed
data.description: Meme coins which are inspired by dog.

data.name: Infrastructure
data.description: Fundamental systems and networks that support the functioning and development of the technology.

data.name: Artificial Intelligence
data.description: Artificial Intelligence (AI) tokens are cryptocurrencies that power AI-related projects, such as AI-powered portfolio management, image generation, path finding, and more.

data.name: 4chan-Themed
data.description: 4chan-themed coins are tokens inspired by 4chan’s meme culture.

data.name: Decentralized Exchange
data.description: Decentralized exchanges (DEXs) allow users to trade with one another in a permissionless manner and without any intermediaries.

data.name: Binance Alpha Spotlight
data.description: Binance Alpha is a platform within Binance Wallet that highlights promising early-stage crypto projects before they potentially list on Binance.

data.name: Privacy Coins
data.description: Privacy coins are cryptocurrencies which allow users to conduct transactions privately and anonymously. This ensures untraceable transactions and the identity of the parties involved are kept private.This is done by hiding the origin and destination of transactions. In some cases, multiple transactions are mixed together in order to make onchain analysis tougher.

data.name: Restaking
data.description: Restaking allows users who have staked their tokens to participate in extending the underlying security of the base network to other protocols and networks.

data.name: YZi Labs Portfolio
data.description: Protocols and tokens that YZi Labs (Prev. Binance Labs) have invested in.

data.name: Perpetuals
data.description: Perpetuals offer traders the ability to take leveraged positions on the price of an asset without owning the underlying asset.

data.name: Index Coop Defi Index
data.description: The DeFi Pulse Index (DPI) is a capitalization-weighted index that tracks the performance of some of the largest protocols in the DeFi space.

data.name: Zero Knowledge
data.description:
Zero-knowledge proof or Zero-knowledge protocol is a method by which one party (the prover) can prove to another party (the verifier) that a given statement is true while the prover avoids conveying any additional information apart from the fact that the statement is indeed true.

This category tracks cryptocurrency that utilises Zero Knowledge implementation to execute transactions, which may include smart contract execution, value transfer, and others.

data.name: Tokenized Assets
data.description: Tokenized products refers to digital representation of assets on a blockchain platform.

data.name: Derivatives
data.description: Derivatives are financial instruments whose value is derived from an underlying asset (e.g. Crude Oil, Gold, Bitcoin etc). Compared to spot markets where the underlying asset changes ownership, in derivatives markets, traders trade contracts rather than the actual assets.

data.name: Chain Abstraction
data.description: Chain abstraction is the concept of creating a seamless, unified user experience across multiple blockchains, allowing users and developers to interact with different chains without needing to manually bridge assets, switch networks, or handle chain-specific complexities.

data.name: Stablecoin Issuer
data.description: Stablecoin issuers are protocols that create and manage stablecoins pegged to assets like fiat by using on-chain mechanisms such as collateralization, liquidity pools, or algorithmic supply adjustments.

data.name: RWA Protocol
data.description: RWA Protocol refer to protocol that facilitates the tokenization of real-world assets.

data.name: Privacy Blockchain
data.description: A privacy blockchain is a smart contract platform designed to prioritize transaction confidentiality and anonymity while maintaining decentralization and security.

data.name: Cross-chain Communication
data.description: Cross-chain communication allows different blockchain networks to interact and exchange data and assets.

data.name: Trump-Affiliated
data.description: This category includes tokens that are officially launched, endorsed, or held by Donald Trump or his immediate family. Only tokens with verifiable affiliation through official statements or reputable sources are included. Community-created tokens or projects that use Trump-related names or slogans without formal connection are excluded.

data.name: Optimism Superchain Ecosystem
data.description: The Optimism Superchain is a unified network of chains built using the open-source OP Stack. This framework provides a standardized, modular architectural framework for creating Layer 2 chains that share a common security and communication layer.

data.name: DePIN
data.description: DePIN refers to Decentralized Physical Infrastructure Networks which utilize blockchain and tokenized incentives to build real-world infrastructure across areas like wireless networks, storage, geolocation, transportation and energy.

data.name: Privacy Infrastructure
data.description: Protocols, networks, and developer tools designed to enable programmable privacy and confidential computation for decentralized applications. Unlike traditional 'Privacy Coins' which focus solely on transactional anonymity, these projects provide the infrastructure for encrypted smart contracts, private state management, and blind computation. They utilize advanced cryptography such as Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs), Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE), and Multi-Party Computation (MPC) to allow developers to build complex applications where data is processed without being publicly revealed.

data.name: Yield Farming
data.description: Yield farming involves putting cryptocurrency into a DeFi protocol to collect interest on trading fees. Liquidity providers can profit by providing liquidity in DeFi protocols like Uniswap, utilizing assets that would otherwise sit idle on an exchange or hot wallet.

data.name: Layer 2
data.description: Layer 2s are off-chain vertical scaling solutions that run on top of Layer 1 blockchains like Ethereum to improve scalability, while maintaining the decentralization and security standards of the Layer 1.

data.name: Oracle
data.description: Oracles are used by protocols in their smart contracts in order to obtain external data. This allows the closed-off blockchain environment to communicate with data points on the outside world. For example, a protocol offering synthetic Nasdaq-listed stock on the blockchain will need to pull external data from the stock market. With an oracle, the protocol will be able to do so.

data.name: x402 Ecosystem
data.description: x402 is an open protocol that defines an internet-native micropayment rail using HTTP 402 and stablecoins. It allows automated clients and AI agents to pay directly for APIs, data, and compute on demand, enabling real-time, low-friction transactions without intermediaries.

data.name: Cybersecurity
data.description: Cybersecurity projects enhance measures through services like smart contract auditing, security analysis, and bug bounty programs.

data.name: Binance Launchpool
data.description: Tokens and coins launched on Binance Launchpool, a platform that allows crypto holders to earn new tokens by locking some of their existing assets.

data.name: NFT
data.description: Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) are collectible elements that represent something unique and therefore are not mutually interchangeable. In other words, no non-fungible token is the same. NFT creators can also encrypt details such as rich metadata or secure file links allowing people to create all sorts of digital assets which are verifiable such as videos and songs.

data.name: Automated Market Maker
data.description: Automated market makers (AMMs) make use of liquidity pools containing 2 or more assets, and prices are derived based on the proportion of each asset in that pool as well as the mathematical function used. Orders through an AMM are executed automatically via a smart contract that will calculate the trade prices algorithmically, including any slippage from the trade execution.

data.name: Layer 0
data.description: Layer 0 is the foundational infrastructure upon which multiple Layer 1 blockchains can be built.

data.name: Quantum-Resistant
data.description: Quantum-resistant projects are characterised by their use of post-quantum cryptographic algorithms (e.g., hash-based, lattice-based) to remain secure against potential attacks from future quantum computers.

data.name: Gaming
data.description: GameFi combines blockchain technology, gaming, and decentralized finance (DeFi), allowing players to earn cryptocurrency and NFT rewards while also offering true ownership and control over in-game assets.

data.name: Directed Acyclic Graph
data.description: A DAG-based blockchain is a type of distributed ledger that uses a graph-like structure instead of a linear chain, allowing faster and parallel transaction processing by linking each transaction to multiple previous ones.

data.name: Solana Meme
data.description: Meme coins native to the Solana network.

data.name: Liquid Staked SOL
data.description: Liquid staked SOL is a tokenized representation of staked SOL that can be traded or used in various DeFi applications.

data.name: Launchpad
data.description: Launchpad is a platform for crypto projects to hold Initial DEX Offerings (IDOs). Participants are able to gain early access to public and special token sales on the platform.

data.name: Lending/Borrowing Protocols
data.description: Lending/borrowing protocols allow users to offer crypto loans by staking their assets in them without the need for a bank account. Users are given rewards, usually in the form of the protocol’s native token.

data.name: Neobank
data.description: A neobank is a digital-only bank that operates online or through mobile apps without physical branches.

data.name: Wallets
data.description: Crypto wallets are digital tools that allow you to interact with blockchain networks to store and manage cryptocurrencies.

data.name: Payment Solutions
data.description: Platforms or services that enable the acceptance and processing of cryptocurrency payments for goods and services.

data.name: Prediction Markets
data.description: A crypto prediction market is a marketplace where people can bet on the outcome of future events using crypto.

data.name: AI Agents
data.description: An AI agent is a smart computer program that can act on its own to achieve goals.

data.name: Metaverse
data.description: The metaverse refers to a digital world where participants can interact with each other in a shared virtual reality.

data.name: Play To Earn
data.description: Play to Earn games are built on the blockchain, giving players full control over their gaming accounts and related assets, which they can sell on exchanges or secondary marketplaces.

data.name: Binance Launchpad
data.description: Tokens and coins launched on Binance Launchpad, a platform that assists blockchain and crypto startups in raising funds.

data.name: Binance HODLer Airdrops
data.description: Binance HODLer Airdrops is an airdrop program by Binance. Users who subscribe to Simple Earn using BNB will receive airdropped tokens issued by projects with a large token circulating supply that intend to soon list on Binance.

data.name: SocialFi
data.description: SocialFi combines social media and DeFi. It aims to bring a more decentralized and user-centric approach to social media platforms, allowing users to monetize their interactions and content directly.

data.name: Binance Wallet IDO
data.description: Tokens and coins launched on Binance Wallet IDO.

data.name: Frog-Themed
data.description: Meme coins which are inspired by frogs.

data.name: Rollup
data.description: Rollup is a layer 2 solution that aggregates and processes transactions outside of a main blockchain, before submitting them as a single batch, to enhance scalability and reduce fees.

data.name: Data Availability
data.description: Data availability on the blockchain ensures that all participants have the transaction data needed to verify blocks, even with resource limitations and scalability needs. Without it, independent verification crumbles, compromising the entire system. Data availability centric protocols aim to allow nodes to verify data availability more efficiently.

data.name: Decentralized Identifier
data.description: Decentralized Identifier (DID) allows individuals or entities to create and manage their own identifiers independently of any centralized registry, identity provider, or intermediary.

data.name: Storage
data.description: Storage protocols allow users to store their data on the blockchain network in a decentralized manner. This negates the need for a centralized storage host such as Amazon, OneDrive, DropBox, and others. This removes the issue of a single point of failure. Decentralized servers make use of independent nodes which in turn use spare storage space on computers. Users are able to rent out their spare storage on  In exchange for storage space, users are able to use a storage protocol’s token to pay for the service.

data.name: Pump.fun Ecosystem
data.description: Pump.fun Ecosystem consists of tokens launched via pump.fun.

data.name: Internet of Things
data.description: The Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystem consists of interconnected computing devices, with the ability to transfer data over a network without the need for any human interaction.

data.name: AI Framework
data.description: An AI Framework/ AI agent framework is a set of tools, libraries, and methodologies designed to facilitate the development, management, and operation of AI agents.

data.name: Analytics
data.description: Projects that provide advanced insights and charting tools to track historical token prices, real-time trades, volume, and many more.

data.name: Masternodes
data.description: Masternodes are needed to verify new blocks in certain cryptocurrencies. However, unlike other nodes, they do not add new blocks to the network. In order to maintain a masternode, one would need to hold a certain amount of the protocol’s cryptocurrency, and it’s usually a significant amount. In return for operating a masternode, the operator is rewarded with the native currency.

data.name: AI Agent Launchpad
data.description: Platforms that allow users to deploy and launch their own AI agents.

data.name: Gaming Blockchains
data.description: Gaming blockchains refer to blockchain platforms specialized in gaming.

data.name: AI Meme
data.description: Meme coins related or inspired by AI. They either leverage AI-powered agents, are created using AI tools, or derive their concept from AI technologies and trends.

data.name: Gaming Utility Token
data.description: Gaming Utility Tokens provide holders with benefits such as making in-game purchases, accessing special content, participating in events, or earning rewards.

data.name: SideChain
data.description: A sidechain is a separate blockchain that runs parallel to a main blockchain. It allows transactions and applications to operate independently to enhance scalability and functionality.

data.name: Bitcoin Sidechains
data.description: Bitcoin Sidechains are designed to enhance the Bitcoin blockchain's capacity by creating a new layer that improves transaction processing speed by handling transactions off the primary chain.

data.name: PolitiFi
data.description:
Political Finance (PolitiFi) are meme coins inspired by political figures.

Note: Most of these tokens have no official affiliation to any political figures.

data.name: Airdropped Tokens by NFT Projects
data.description: Airdropped tokens by NFT Projects refer to tokens distributed by NFT projects as part of their community engagement or ecosystem expansion initiatives. Airdrops are often tied to ownership of specific NFT collections or eligibility within certain user groups.

data.name: Dex Aggregator
data.description: A DEX aggregator is designed to enhance the efficiency and accessibility of cryptocurrency trading. It searches across multiple decentralized exchanges (DEXs) to combine their liquidity, helping users avoid slippage on large orders, lower trading fees, and secure the best prices for tokens.

data.name: Liquid Staking Governance Tokens
data.description: Liquid Staking Governance Tokens facilitate decision-making and policy formation in Liquid Staking Token Protocols, allowing holders to influence asset allocation and platform strategy.

data.name: IP Meme
data.description: Meme projects tied to verifiable IP assets.

data.name: Name Service
data.description: Name Service is a decentralized naming system that allows users to map human-readable domain names to machine-readable information.

data.name: Parallelized EVM
data.description: Parallel EVM refers to the capability of processing and executing multiple blockchain transactions simultaneously rather than in a sequential manner.

data.name: Binance Buildkey TGE
data.description: The BuildKey TGE Model is a hybrid Token Generation Event (TGE) framework developed by Aspecta in collaboration with Binance Wallet.

data.name: Sports
data.description:
These projects have introduced a new way for sports teams to engage with their fans and has made it easier for ordinary sports fans to show their support to their favorite teams and players. 
With Fan Tokens and NFTs, fans have the power to influence their favourite sports teams in minor decisions and enter an exclusive club of like-minded supporters and VIP benefits.

data.name: Gaming Governance Token
data.description: Gaming Governance Token gives holders the right to participate in development and decision making process of the game.

data.name: Curve Ecosystem
data.description: Interconnected platforms and services built around Curve Finance.

data.name: Liquid Restaking Governance Tokens
data.description: Liquid Restaking Governance Tokens facilitate decision-making and policy formation in Liquid Restaking Token Protocols, allowing holders to influence asset allocation and platform strategy.

data.name: BTCfi Protocol
data.description: BTCfi Protocol refers to DeFi protocols built on or around the Bitcoin ecosystem. It aims to bring DeFi activities such as lending, borrowing, and yield farming to Bitcoin holders.

data.name: Modular Blockchain
data.description: A modular blockchain is a type of blockchain architecture that separates the core functions of a blockchain into distinct modules or layers. Each module is designed to handle specific tasks independently.

data.name: MEV Protection
data.description: MEV (Maximal Extractable Value) protection is a set of rules and mechanisms designed to prevent or mitigate the negative impacts of MEV in decentralized finance (DeFi) environments.

data.name: IP
data.description: Intellectual property (IP) related crypto projects leverage blockchain technology to tokenize and manage intellectual property, enabling transparent ownership, automated royalties, and decentralized marketplaces for creators and investors.

data.name: DeFAI
data.description: DeFAI or AIFI projects leverage AI to streamline and automate DeFi activities such as trading, staking, yield farming, market analysis, and investment optimization.

data.name: Account Abstraction
data.description: Account abstraction aims to simplify the way users interact with dApps by doing away with the complexities of gas fees and transaction management.

data.name: Entertainment
data.description: Projects that are specifically designed to be used within the entertainment sector, which may include areas such as music, film, gaming, and other forms of digital media.

data.name: Telegram Apps
data.description: Applications built on the Telegram platform that integrate cryptocurrency or blockchain technology.

data.name: Cat-Themed
data.description: Meme coins which are inspired by cat.

data.name: RPG
data.description: Role-playing game (RPG) is a video game genre where players control a single or group of character in a fictional world. RPG games typically include elements of storytelling, character development, exploration, quests, and inventory management.

data.name: Simulation Games
data.description: Simulation game replicates real-world activities, offering players the opportunity to experience different skills or activities in a virtual environment.

data.name: Murad Picks
data.description: Tokens promoted by a memecoin KOL @MustStopMurad.

data.name: Gaming Platform
data.description: Gaming platform allows users to play, download, and manage video games. They often provide features like multiplayer matchmaking, community forums, and in-game purchases.

data.name: Synthetic
data.description: This category includes both synthetic asset issuers and the synthetic assets themselves. Synthetic assets are on-chain tokens that replicate the price behavior of another asset, whether it’s a fiat currency, commodity, or stock using smart contracts and price oracles.

data.name: Bridge Governance Tokens
data.description: A bridge governance token is a type of cryptocurrency token that is used to manage and govern a blockchain bridge.

data.name: Four.meme Ecosystem
data.description: Four.meme Ecosystem consists of tokens launched via four.meme on BNB Chain.

data.name: Buidlpad Launchpad
data.description: Buidlpad is a launchpad that enables token sales with KYC-verified participants.

data.name: Card Games
data.description: Crypto card games are digital card games that utilize blockchain technology allowing players to collect, trade, and play with unique digital cards often represented as NFTs.

data.name: LSDFi
data.description: Liquid Staking Derivatives Finance (LSDFi) combines the principles of liquid staking derivatives with traditional DeFi applications to offer enhanced financial opportunities and flexibility to cryptocurrency users.

data.name: Yield Aggregator
data.description: Yield aggregators are protocols that collate multiple yield farms in a single place in order to ease the process of farming. With many new farms popping up on the market, it can be tedious for one to hop from farm to farm. However, with yield aggregators, that isn’t necessary as it’s done automatically in order to maximize the yield generated for users.

data.name: Base Meme
data.description: Meme coins native to the Base network.

data.name: TokenFi Launchpad
data.description: TokenFi Launchpad is a platform for crypto projects to hold Initial DEX Offerings (IDOs). Participants are able to gain early access to public and special token sales on the platform.

data.name: Avalanche L1
data.description: Avalanche L1 are specialized sets of validators on Avalanche that allow the creation of customized independent networks with specific rules and governance to enable scalable and tailored blockchain solutions for various applications.

data.name: Decentralized Science
data.description: Decentralized Science aims to leverage the blockchain and Web3 tools to create an open ecosystem to conduct, and disseminate scientific research.

data.name: Synthetic Issuer
data.description: Issuer of synthetic asset.

data.name: Intent
data.description: Intents are signed messages that simplify on-chain goals. They are handled by solvers to enhance user experiences, optimize transactions, and incentivize efficient execution paths.

data.name: InfoFi
data.description: InfoFi combines blockchain and AI to monetise and trade attention, influence, and data as assets. It uses decentralised platforms to aggregate, verify, and distribute information, enabling users to be rewarded from their engagement or content.

data.name: NFT Marketplace
data.description: A NFT marketplace is a platform where users can buy, sell, and trade NFTs.

data.name: Fan Token
data.description: Fan tokens let sporting organizations and other celebrities engage with their communities, where holders can access exclusive benefits.

data.name: Appchains
data.description: An appchain (application-specific blockchain) is a specialized blockchain designed to optimize performance and efficiency, tailored for particular tasks or specific use cases.

data.name: Yearn Ecosystem
data.description: Interconnected platforms and services built around Yearn.

data.name: Rollups-as-a-Service
data.description: Rollups-as-a-Service (RaaS) streamlines the deployment and maintenance of custom application-specific rollups by offering a simplified interface including no-code deployment options.

data.name: Zoo-Themed
data.description: Meme coins related to animals in the zoo.

data.name: Layer 3
data.description: Layer 3 protocols are built on Layer 2, enabling hosting of application-specific decentralized applications while addressing issues such as scalability, interoperability and customization.

data.name: Music
data.description: Cryptocurrency projects that are related to music is aimed at disrupting the record publishing industry. The goal is to simplify the process of tracking, collecting, and distributing song royalties to musicians in a decentralized manner. Fans are also able to directly support their favorite artists directly without going through an intermediary.

data.name: Olympus Pro Ecosystem
data.description: Olympus Pro designed to provide liquidity management solutions for DeFi protocols. They offers a service called "bonds-as-a-service," which allows protocols to own their liquidity by offering discounted OHM tokens in exchange for liquidity provider (LP) tokens. This helps protocols to reduce their reliance on liquidity mining incentives and gain more control over their liquidity.

data.name: Action Games
data.description: Fast-paced games that emphasize combat, reflexes, and real-time challenges.

data.name: Runes
data.description: Runes is a token standard on Bitcoin that improve the creation of fungible tokens on the blockchain.

data.name: Bitcoin Meme
data.description: Meme coins native to the Bitcoin network.

data.name: Parody Meme
data.description: Meme coins which are inspired by the names of well-known brands, individuals, or cultural icons.

data.name: Clanker Ecosystem
data.description: Clanker Ecosystem consists of tokens launched via Clanker, an autonomous memecoin launcher.

data.name: Energy
data.description: Projects focused on renewable energy, green technology, and sustainable practices within the cryptocurrency ecosystem.

data.name: MMO
data.description: Online games that host large numbers of players.

data.name: Tap to Earn
data.description: Tap-to-earn (T2E) combines simple and addictive gameplay with the potential to earn cryptocurrency. These games, often hosted on platforms like Telegram, allow users to earn digital assets by performing actions such as repeatedly tapping on a screen.

data.name: Tokenized Real Estate
data.description: Tokenized real estate in crypto refers to the integration of blockchain technology and cryptocurrencies into the real estate market. This can involve tokenizing real estate assets, which means dividing the ownership of a property into digital tokens that can be bought, sold, or traded on a blockchain. This allows for fractional ownership, where multiple investors can own a portion of a property.

data.name: Move To Earn
data.description: The move-to-earn model is often implemented through mobile applications that use technologies such as GPS tracking to monitor users' physical activity. These apps then reward users with tradable tokens or NFTs based on the distance they cover or the number of steps they take.

data.name: Binance Megadrop
data.description: Binance Megadrop is an airdrop program by Binance. It allows users to earn rewards by subscribing to BNB to Locked Products and completing tasks within their Binance Web3 Wallet.

data.name: Capital Launchpad
data.description: Capital Launchpad is a Web3 crowdfunding platform by Kaito that connects early-stage crypto projects with investors through a merit-based allocation system.

data.name: BNB Chain Ecosystem
data.description:
BNB Chain is an alternative blockchain that is similar to Ethereum, capable of hosting smart contracts and decentralized applications. It was launched by Binance in September 2020 as the Binance Smart Chain, and relaunched in Feburary 2022 as BNB Chain. BNB uses the Proof-of-Staked-Authority model which has allowed for low transaction fees and higher throughput. 

Compared to Ethereum which would usually cost hundreds to make a few transactions, BNB only charges less than a few dollars. BNB supports the BEP-20 token format, which is essentially the same format as ERC-20 but on a different chain, and transaction fees are paid in Binance’s native exchange token, BNB.

data.name: Solana Ecosystem
data.description: Solana is a general purpose blockchain similar to Ethereum. The underlying architecture is different, such that developers have to write applications using Rust instead of Solidity or Vyper. However, this may soon change with the introduction of the Neon EVM solution on Solana. End user applications as of now include decentralized finance (DeFi), non-fungible tokens (NFT), marketplaces, games, and more. One of its biggest features is its scalability in which Solana is able to process over 700,000 transactions per second. Its high throughput capability appeals to high frequency traders, which is spearheaded by FTX and Alameda Research. The first use case for DeFi applications on Solana is Serum, built by the team behind FTX.

data.name: Polygon Ecosystem
data.description: Polygon, formerly known as Matic, was originally meant to be a Layer-2 scaling solution for Ethereum to improve transaction throughput and speed. However, it has since become more popular as a stand-alone blockchain, with its own native projects and decentralized applications. Major DeFi protocols such as Aave and Curve have also found second homes on Polygon. Unlike Ethereum, Polygon operates on Proof-of-Stake (PoS) in which network participants can stake the network’s native MATIC tokens to validate transactions and participate in voting and other governance decisions. Polygon also hosts its own bridge that allows users to transfer assets from Ethereum to Polygon and vice versa.

data.name: Avalanche Ecosystem
data.description: Avalanche is a smart contract platform that allows users to create their own multi-purpose blockchains or decentralized applications (dApps). Their mainnet was launched in September 2020 and has since become a major hub of activity for DeFi and NFTs. In 2021, they announced their Avalanche Rush incentives program to introduce more applications and to promote further growth of their ecosystem. The Avalanche chain is centered around 3 main blockchains - the P-Chain, X-Chain and C-Chain. The C-Chain is Avalanche’s EVM implementation, which hosts various applications and smart contracts. Users can access Avalanche through centralized exchanges, the official Avalanche bridge or via Celer’s cBridge.

data.name: Fantom Ecosystem
data.description:
FANTOM is a new DAG-based smart contract platform that intends to solve the scalability issues of existing public distributed ledger technologies.
The platform intends to distinguish itself from the traditional block ledger-based storage infrastructure by attempting to employ an improved version of existing DAG-based protocols. Fantom adopts a new protocol known as the “Lachesis Protocol” to maintain consensus. This protocol is intended to be integrated into the Fantom Opera Chain. The aim is to allow applications built on Fantom to enjoy instant transactions and near zero transaction costs for all users.

data.name: TON Ecosystem
data.description: Protocols built on The Open Network (TON), a blockchain designed using technology from Telegram.

data.name: Gnosis Chain Ecosystem
data.description: Formerly the xDai Chain, The Gnosis chain is a Layer 2 scaling solution for Ethereum but uses a different consensus algorithm - Proof of Stake (PoS) and Proof of Stake DAO (POSDAO). It is designed to be more efficient than Ethereum, with higher transaction throughput (70 transactions/second) and has a much lower transaction fee.

data.name: Harmony Ecosystem
data.description: Harmony is a blockchain platform that is designed to act as a bridge between scalability and interoperability. Its focus is on processing speed and validation of blocks. It can be used to create decentralized applications (DApps), and is currently focused on random state sharding. This will then allow the creation of blocks within seconds.

data.name: Near Protocol Ecosystem
data.description: NEAR is a sharded, developer-friendly, proof-of-stake public blockchain. It is designed to compete with Ethereum by providing a similar experience with decentralized applications and smart contracts, but with lower fees and higher throughput. The blockchain’s native token, NEAR, is used to pay for transactions and storing data on the blockchain. Smart contract developers receive a portion of the transaction fees generated by their contracts, while the remainder is burnt. This creates deflationary pressure on NEAR, making it more valuable as more transactions are performed.

data.name: Berachain Ecosystem
data.description: Berachain is an EVM-compatible blockchain built on Proof-of-Liquidity consensus.

data.name: Scroll Ecosystem
data.description: Scroll is a Layer 2 network that aims to extend Ethereum's capabilities through zero knowledge (ZK) tech and EVM compatibility.

data.name: Cosmos Ecosystem
data.description: Cosmos focuses on blockchain interoperability, working towards the vision of building the “Internet of Blockchains.”

data.name: Polkadot Ecosystem
data.description: Polkadot is a blockchain protocol designed to support multiple purpose-built blockchains under one unified network. Polkadot’s infrastructure begins with the relay chain, which acts as the central chain. Each chain that runs on Polkadot is called a parachain as they run parallel to the main relay chain, and is built on top of the relay chain. Besides parachains, projects can participate in the Polkadot ecosystem for a shorter fixed period of time through parathreads. Blockchains built on top of Polkadot’s own relay chain are also interoperable with blockchains that have vastly different technology stacks such as Ethereum and Bitcoin through bridges.

data.name: Terra Ecosystem
data.description: Terra is a blockchain network that builds on the Tendermint consensus (Proof-of-Stake) and the Cosmos SDK toolkit. Terra’s network token is LUNA which powers the entire ecosystem. Unlike most blockchains, Terra’s ecosystem includes a native algorithmic stablecoin, TerraUSD (UST). A decentralized network with its own decentralized currency is a very attractive thesis for both users and developers. More dApps are being built on Terra, especially DeFi protocols which are now commonly known as TeFi.

data.name: Ronin Ecosystem
data.description: Protocols that are built on the Ronin network, an EVM-compatible blockchain designed for games.

data.name: Manta Network Ecosystem
data.description: Protocols that are built on the Manta network, an EVM-compatible ZK-application platform.

data.name: Neon Ecosystem
data.description: Neon is an on-chain solution that brings native Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) dApps to the Solana network without any reconfiguration.
